messages.content:
I want to deposit into a contract and receive back a signed commitment of my balance or a proof.  I think there are a few competing problems with this and would love some input on potential solutions:

a) proofs are not serializable (yet?) which makes them a finicky type to rely on for an IOU

b) the contract does not expose its own private key to the user so a signature seems potentially impossible to use in lieu of a proof

c) returning from a method could result in a proof or signature but then the deposit might not actually ever be mined, so I could have an IOU for money I never deposited

So does this require that I use a state storage, maybe a merkle map to store state, then base a proof off of that state?  I was hoping to avoid having such storage because I don't want the user to know everyone's balances, just their own.
And to add a new key to the merkle map, will I need a proof that the key does not yet exist in the map?

a) i'd say proofs are fully serialisable since you can do `proof.toJSON()` and it will give you a json proof, same goes for the verification key (its just a string actually) - in case you need to verify the proofs at any point

b) one approach would be to store the commitment in a merkle tree, once the balances have been transfered offchain (merkle tree  just holds the entry confirming the deed was done). Then you could look up if the user is in the tree and this would serve as a 'proof' that the deposit was done. Keep in mind that the proof itself does not indicate directly that the transaction was successfully included on-chain, threfore you need to rely on finalised contract state to be sure. Maybe there's a gap in my thinking but i think this train of thought should be valid, i'll let others chip in too.

c) i think you've pointed to what i've tried to explain in b)
You could also just something like account bound token
@Florian with an token, everyone who uses my app would need to pay a 1 Mina account creation fee right?

@maht0rz yeah a proof that a deposit was done that doesn’t actually prove a deposit was done ends up being pretty useless… i am pursuing the merkle tree state approach but I’m not sure how to build the proof correctly that the transition from root a to root b is valid since I can’t include tree a in the method parameters.  I must be able to use the MerkleMapWitness class somehow to make the proof but I’m not sure syntactically how to use that class.  For instance assert account a is not in the map, assert account a is in the new map, assert account a’s balance in the new map is equal to the amount they deposit.  That seems like a feasible approach I just don’t know how to do it…
you could also emit an event / action
yes - but only for the first deposit
why not just store Poseidon.hash([from, to, amount]) in the merkle tree as a result of the sucessful deposit?

I think a merkle map of account -> balance makes the most sense of the merkle options.  Maybe a tree of accounts is fine too like the example in the docs.  Hashing the deposit itself doesn’t seem very helpful if a user can make more than one deposit.  And then if a user wants to use their balance to take an action, you need to be able to decrement the balance too.  I think any user’s balance in the app should be provable which lends itself to the token solution, but I don’t think charging to create an account is a great design choice when an alternative would work.
you can attach a random identifier to allow for multiple deposits so the hash is unique
or.. you can increment the existing deposit in the tree

What I don't understand about updating a merkle tree or map, is I can only include a witness in the method params, so I have to update the leaf, set the new root in the state, but I never have the whole tree.

So let's say I have my tree off chain, I call the deposit method and update my local tree.  The transaction gets mined and we're all set 👍 

But let's say 1000 users all do a deposit and some of the transactions fail, how do I keep my local tree in sync?  It seems plausible that I successfully update the root hash on chain but lose track of which updates actually occurred in my local tree, then I can't recreate a valid witness.

Question for @Florian or @gregor : with a merkle map, will each key be independent of updates to other keys, such that a witness of key1 will be valid in the same block as key2 has been updated and changed the root hash?  Any merkle-based solution seems bad if the throughput is one deposit per 3 minutes anyways...

To elaborate on "What I don't understand about updating a merkle tree or map" - the intuitive API for me is I include the entire tree in the method, I compute the hash of the entire tree and prove it's correct, then I update the tree and recompute the root, and set it.

Maybe this is naive and way too slow or something.  So my understanding based on the example in the docs is that you take a witness of a given path and say "if the value of the leaf at this path is `myVal` then compute the root hash" and if that hash matches, it functions as a proof that the value of the leaf at that location is indeed `myVal`.  Then you say "Suppose I change the value to be `myNewVal`, then the updated hash would be `newHash`.  So you set newHash as the state.  But we never actually made a tree with root `newHash`.  The result of calling that method is either that our root hash is unchanged or that our root hash has changed, and if it has, we need to make the same change we suggested in the proof.  I guess what I find brittle about this other than trying to keep track of whether the tx was successful or not is that `witness.computeRoot(newVal)` and `tree.setLeaf(path, newVal)` are different APIs and you could potentially get different results.  Like you do one thing on chain and a different thing off chain and they should be equal as long as snarkyjs is implemented correctly, but if there's a bug then your on chain state is lost.

If you have two proofs accessing the same tree (root), only one proof (the first) will succeed if the root is being changed afterwards, thats a bit of an disadvantage of merkle trees. every single change in the tree renders all other proofs invalid

you dont have to include the entire tree in your method, using a merkle witness lets you do that fine. You can check if a leaf is includes in the tree, make some changes to it, calculate the new root and set the new root - so your assumption is correct
But ye, its a bit of a pain to keep the on-chain state in sync with the off-chain one.. You could use events to try and fix that, for example.
Makes sense... then tokens look pretty attractive 😄
I think I'll try the merkle approach first as a PoC.  But it does seem like it ends up being a little goofy if you imagine an app with a lot of actual users
Merkle trees are an easy way of referencing off-chain data, but the disadvantage are the logistics of keeping the state in sync
OTOH, if we imagine a clean native storage solution, then the merkle trees look good again.
Events seem like a decent way to stay in sync.
i think a good short term solution would be using the events system
ye
I was brainstorming a small api a while ago, but no time to implement it
I think out of the latest builder's program came some working examples of how to solve this problem -- Merkle trees + user concurrency
The emerging pattern is to dispatch the Merkle tree updates as actions and do the actual Merkle root updating inside `Reducer.reduce`

That sounds promising!  Can you elaborate?  Is this something that can work right now?

It seems like one could emit actions with the witness, but then after one iteration of reduce, wouldn't the `i`th witness no longer be valid?  Or would it be, since we're not updating the same keys?
Well no, this would still only set the root to be the original state updated with the last update to go through.  Not updated by each update in a row.  So what am I missing?
We are using this pattern when we accumulate all votes in our voting example
https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/blob/main/src/examples/zkapps/voting/voting.ts

messages.content:
hi, @45930, did this work for you?
```const depositUpdate = AccountUpdate.create(player);
depositUpdate.send({ to: this.address, amount: new UInt64(amount) });```
i've been trying to do the same, but i get this error at runtime:
```TypeError: this.magnitude.value.mul is not a function
    at Int64.toField
    at Int64.sub
    at AccountUpdate.send```

oh, nevermind, the issue was the way i was instantiating UInt64 ( "new UInt64(10)" vs new "UInt64(Field(10))" )

anyways, hi, everyone! i hope to finish my demo before the deadline 😬
alternatively I would recommend to use `UInt64.from(x)`
you are right, that's a lot cleaner, thanks!
